node.text:
⁣

⭐Be sure to tag an expecting mama!⭐⁣
⁣
Breastfeeding can feel so overwhelming. Especially in those early days when both you AND your little one aren't quite sure if you're doing it right. Today, I'd love to give you a SIMPLE way to think about it so that it doesn't feel quite as overwhelming.⁣
⁣
Here are a few quick takeaways:⁣
➡️Remove those extra blankets and clothing. Being skin-to-skin with mom prepares the baby for a good feeding.⁣
➡️Your baby’s belly button should face your belly button during a feeding. (Double-check to make sure it’s NOT facing the ceiling.)⁣
➡️Make a “C” with your hand to help fit the entire areola into your baby’s mouth. No “scissor-fingers.”⁣
➡️If your little one is falling asleep, wake that baby! Our goal is a full feeding instead of snacking.⁣
➡️And most importantly, remember: Reach out for help if you need it. IBCLCs are worth their weight in gold! ⁣
⁣
You got this, Mama! No one could do it better, because YOU are the best mama on the planet for your baby... no matter how you feed that sweet little one!🥰⁣
⁣
If you enjoyed this, and your little one is struggling with sleep, you'll love my online classes — taught from the science of a nurse and the heart of a mom! Just click the link in my bio and select your baby's age.❤️⁣
⁣
Will you share with me where you're at in your breastfeeding journey? Any words of encouragement for new moms who are just starting out?

⁣

node.title: Breastfeeding Basics: featuring a Subway Sandwich 🥪😂⁣

node.text:
⁣
⁣
Bath time...just another tool in your parenting toolbox! 🛠️⁣
⁣
⭐𝘋𝘪𝘥 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸: Science actually supports a bath as part of the bedtime routine?⭐⁣
⁣
It’s true! Here’s why: ⁣
⁣
During a warm bath, blood comes to the surface of the skin. This is called vasodilation. When we get out of the tub, blood vessels are still open, so our body temperature drops a bit. This slight drop in core body temp promotes sleep for us and our babies!⁣
⁣
Baths can be so helpful, especially:⁣
✅At the end of the day: A bath given as part of a bedtime routine tells your baby’s brain that bedtime is near. This is a great way to prepare babies for night sleep.⁣
✅During awake time: Need an activity? A bath is like a giant water table filled with toys!⁣
✅When baby is fussy: The warm bath water can be very calming for cranky babies.⁣
⁣
“𝘋𝘰𝘦𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘦𝘢𝘯 𝘐 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘣𝘢𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘮𝘺 𝘣𝘢𝘣𝘺 𝘌𝘝𝘌𝘙𝘠 𝘯𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵!?”⁣
⁣
⁣My answer: Do what works best for YOUR family!⁣
➡️ Some parents prefer the consistency of a daily bath. (Soap is optional if his skin is dry...and don’t forget to lather him in lotion afterward!) ⁣
➡️ Others choose to do it every other day or even every third day. ⁣
There's no right or wrong answer. 💕⁣
⁣
Do baths relax or energize your baby? When’s your favorite time to give him/her a bath?⁣

node.text:
Let’s talk about BABY ACNE!⁣
⁣
You may notice small red bumps across your newborn's face. The bumps can even look irritated or a bit inflamed when he cries. ⁣If you’ve never seen it before, it can cause your alarm bells 🚨 to start ringing. “Is my baby sick? Is she having a reaction to something?” ⁣
⁣
Let me reassure you! Baby acne is so common within the first few weeks of life and not in any way harmful to your little one, but it’s always a good idea to have your doctor see it.⁣
⁣
“Alright...but what can I do about the baby acne?!” Here are a few tips: ⁣
⁣
DO:⁣
✅Gently wash using a clean washcloth and water⁣.⁣
✅Pat baby’s face dry after washing⁣.⁣
✅Keep baby’s face clear of spit-up.⁣
✅Allow time for the acne to clear up.⁣
✅Continue taking so many pictures of your beautiful baby!⁣
⁣
DON’T:⁣
🚫Use acne treatments. ⁣
🚫Use scented baby washes.⁣
🚫Pinch, pick, rub, or squeeze baby acne. ⁣
🚫Apply lotion.⁣
⁣
The good news is: Baby acne will usually clear up on its own within a couple of weeks!⁣
⁣
Did your baby have acne? If so, how long did it last? Tag a new/expectant parent so that baby acne doesn’t take them by surprise!

node.text:
“𝘞𝘢𝘪𝘵 𝘢 𝘮𝘪𝘯𝘶𝘵𝘦 𝘊𝘢𝘳𝘢...𝘠𝘰𝘶 𝘸𝘢𝘯𝘵 𝘮𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘱𝘶𝘵 𝘮𝘺 𝘣𝘢𝘣𝘺 𝘪𝘯 𝘢 “𝘚𝘈𝘊𝘒” 𝘵𝘰 𝘴𝘭𝘦𝘦𝘱?!?⁣”⁣
⁣
YES! I love using “sleep sacks” once a baby transitions out of the swaddle... through age 2+! 💗💗💗⁣
⁣
𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝘃𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗼 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻:  ⁣
✅ The benefits of a sleep sack⁣
✅ When to use a sleep sack⁣
✅ What's a “TOG rating” and how can it help⁣
✅ When you should stop using a sleep sack⁣
✅ Some of my favorite brands⁣
⁣
Do you HAVE to use a sleep sack? Of course not!⁣
But I do think they can be helpful tools for great baby sleep!⁣
⁣
If you are dealing with sleep struggles that a sleep sack just won’t fix, click the link in bio. I have online courses and resources that will help you!⁣ 💕⁣
⁣
Does your little one wear a sleep sack? What’s your favorite brand and why? What was the most helpful thing you learned from this video?⁣
⁣
𝘚𝘭𝘦𝘦𝘱 𝘣𝘢𝘨𝘴/𝘴𝘢𝘤𝘬𝘴 𝘧𝘦𝘢𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦𝘥 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘷𝘪𝘥𝘦𝘰: @halosleep, @woolino, @kytebaby, @nestedbean, @snuggybuddybaby

node.title: Sleep Sacks, Sleep Bags, Wearable Blankets

node.text:
If you're struggling with naps while in quarantine, these 10 tips are for YOU!💤⁣
⁣
But first, I need to share something with you: This video was filmed back in March — when getting outside was much easier, and there weren't as many closures and restrictions. Honestly, we had NO idea what the rest of 2020 would look like.⁣
⁣
We're getting into the winter months now, with colder weather and less daylight. Some places are entering another wave of lockdown. This means that you're going to have to be even more creative with your awake time activities!⁣
⁣
Can I ask...⁣
➡️Which tip did you find most helpful?⁣
➡️Which one do you really need to focus on?⁣
➡️How are you helping your baby get physical during this season?⁣
➡️Is going outside even an option where you live? ⁣
⁣
Please remember: your little one can read you like a BOOK. 📖⁣
It's true! Babies may not know that there's a pandemic, but they know that something is different. Challenging naps are NOT uncommon when life gets a bit derailed from our norm.⁣
⁣
Head to today's stories for links to all the resources I mentioned in this video. I truly hope this is helpful. ⁣
⁣
Tag another parent! We are all in this together! And...you've got this!💪

In honor of #WorldBreastfeedingWeek, I'd like to give you a SIMPLE way to think about breastfeeding basics, so it doesn’t feel quite so overwhelming. (Hopefully, this makes you giggle a little too!).⁣
⁣
Tag an expectant mama!⁣
And...If you enjoyed this, you'll love my online sleep classes — taught from the science of a nurse and the heart of a mom! ❤️⁣
⁣
Here's what these lactation consultants had to say:⁣

🤱🏽”This is such a great visual to show moms how they can help their baby get a nice, deep latch! I share it in all of my class and consult handouts." Sarah, IBCLC @milksprouts⁣
⁣
(P.S Now I’m hungry… @subway Send dinner please! 😋)

node.text:
YES! YES! YES! ⁣
⁣
➡️ Why is a sound machine helpful?⁣
It replicates the womb and helps babies fall asleep and stay asleep. It also blocks out extraneous noises that can wake a sleeping baby. ⁣
⁣
➡️ Should it automatically shut off?⁣
We want the noise to stay on. Shutting off can actually wake a baby. Check out the video to see this happen!⁣
⁣
➡️ How loud should it be?⁣
About the level of a running shower. Think about this: a running shower never hurts your ears, but you do have to speak louder to be heard. ⁣
⁣
➡️ Why do some say it shouldn’t be more than 50 dB?⁣
It has been recommended to hospital NICUs not to have an environment of more than 50 decibels because little ones never get a break from the noise in the NICU.⁣
⁣
OSHA adult standards say no more than 85 decibels for up to 8 hours. ⁣
*️⃣ Know this: The baseline inside the womb is 72-88db.⁣
(Research linked in stories.)⁣
⁣
In 2014, a study showed that many sound machines are capable of being louder than 85 dB. ⁣
⁣
➕Bottom line, turn it to the lowest level that helps baby sleep and blocks out extraneous noise, and try to keep it at a good distance from baby while sleeping.⁣ (Again, think shower volume.)⁣
⁣
➡️ I heard sound machines cause processing disorders. Is that true? ⁣
In 2003, there was a study where rats were exposed to constant white noise; they did see processing concerns. However, those rats were never given a break nor exposed to normal noise/language. This is NOT our goal. We only use sound machines for sleep and expose babies to normal noise/language while awake. The speech-language pathologists and audiologists I have spoken to all use sound machines with their own children while making sure to keep it at the lowest effective volume. ⁣
⁣
➡️ When do I wean it? ⁣
I recommend it for at least the first two years. If you want to wean it, just turn it down a tiny bit every other night until it’s gone. ⁣(PS- you don’t *have* to wean it. I still sleep with one! 😳😂)
⁣
Want to see the research? Check out today's stories!⁣
⁣
*This is not medical advice. Feel free to talk with your doctor and trust your gut. As a parent, you get to make the best decision for YOUR baby.

node.text: Cara has a 5 week old sleep over. You will learn about naps, bedtime routines, nighttime wakings and feedings, sleepy cues, feedings, and how to put them all together! If you want to learn more, I have a newborn class for you! (This is a saved highlight on my profile if you want to watch it with the swipe ups. It’s called “Sleepover”.)

node.title: A Day in the Life with a Newborn

node.text:
Within the first few weeks of life, baby acne is so common. You may notice small red bumps across your newborn's face. The bumps can even look irritated or a bit inflamed when he cries. ⁣
⁣
If you’ve never seen this before, it can cause your alarm bells 🚨 to start ringing. “Is my baby sick? Is she having a reaction to something?” ⁣
⁣
Let me reassure you! Baby acne is very normal and not in any way harmful to your little one, but it’s always a good idea to have your doctor see it.⁣
⁣
“Alright Cara...but what can I do about the baby acne?!” Here are a few tips: ⁣
⁣
𝗗𝗢’𝘀: ⁣
✅ Do wash with a clean washcloth and water⁣
✅ Do pat baby’s face dry after washing⁣
✅ Do keep baby’s face clear of spit up ⁣
✅ Do allow time for the acne to clear up.⁣
✅ Do take so many pictures of your beautiful baby!⁣
⁣
𝗗𝗢𝗡’𝗧’𝘀: ⁣
🚫 Don’t use creams or acne treatments. ⁣
🚫 Don’t use scented baby washes.⁣
🚫 Don’t pinch, pick, or squeeze baby acne. ⁣
🚫 Don’t apply lotion.⁣
⁣
Baby acne will usually clear up on it’s own within a couple of weeks!⁣
⁣
Did your baby have acne? How long did it last? Will you tag an expectant parent so baby acne doesn’t take them by surprise?

node.text:
You want me to put my baby in a “SACK” to sleep?!?⁣
⁣
YES! I love using “sleep sacks” once a baby transitions out of the swaddle... through age 2+! ❤️️❤️️⁣
⁣
𝗪𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝘃𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗼 𝘁𝗼 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿: ⁣
✅ The benefits of a sleep sack⁣
✅ When to use a sleep sack⁣
✅ What's a TOG rating and how can it help⁣
✅ When you should stop using a sleep sack⁣
✅ Some of my favorite brands⁣
⁣
Do you HAVE to use a sleep sack? Of course not!⁣
But I do think they can be helpful tools for great baby sleep!😴⁣
⁣
If you're needing more sleep help than just a sleep sack, click the link in bio. I have online courses and resources that will help you!⁣
⁣
Does your baby wear a sleep sack? What’s your favorite brand and why? What was the most helpful thing you learned from this video?⁣
⁣
Sleep bags/sacks featured in this video: @nestedbean, @halosleep, @woolino, @kytebaby, @snuggybuddybaby

node.title: Sleep Sacks, Sleep Bags, Wearable Blankets

node.text:
After watching this video, which is you favorite technique for burping YOUR baby:
1️⃣putting baby up and over the shoulder
2️⃣making a “c” with your hand and holding upright
3️⃣laying baby across the lap
Were any of these techniques new to you? Is there one you’re wanting to try today?
Tag an expectant/new parent as this info can be so helpful!
-
How often should you burp a baby?
🌟Burp your baby mid-way through a feeding and at the end of a feeding.🌟
-
While some babies need more frequent burping, most do great with this frequency.
Sometimes, parents burp too frequently and this can lead to a hungry and fussy baby or one who loses interest in the feeding.
-
What if you can’t get your baby to burp?
🌟 If you find that one method isn’t producing a burp, try switching methods. Oftentimes, switching your burping technique is all it takes! Give your baby 3-4 minutes, and if there’s still no burp, then go ahead and continue the feeding or be done. (Some babies just don’t take in much air during feedings.)
-
🌟 At what age do babies get burps out on their own?
Every baby is different, but typically between 4-6 months.
-
Unfortunately, babies don’t come with manuals —  but Taking Cara Babies can help you navigate this new season! If you have a baby 12 weeks or younger, check out the No-Cry Newborn Sleep Class where you’ll learn to calm a fussy baby, read your little one’s cues, set your days and nights up for success, and truly enjoy that newborn phase. 🙌

node.title: Three Ways to Burp a Newborn

node.text:
QUESTION: Should my baby use a pacifier??
-
ANSWER: It’s up to you and your little one! 💕
-
There truly is no “right or wrong” approach when it comes to pacifiers. 
Some babies never take a pacifier, and that’s okay!
However, for many babies, pacifiers are helpful tools for comfort and relaxation.
-
Why might you consider using a pacifier? Science shows us that pacifiers:
👉 Release endorphins
👉 Promote relaxation
👉 Decrease the risk of SIDS
👉 Help keep baby calm
-
⭐ If you hope to use a pacifier, for best results, offer in the first 1-3weeks of life.⭐
-
“But Cara, I’m a nursing mom...can my baby still have a pacifier?”
-
YES. 💗 It’s a common misconception that pacifiers cause nipple confusion for breastfed babies. However, research shows us that nursing moms who introduce a pacifier early are JUST as successful with nursing as those who don’t. (Research link in my pacifier blog. See stories.)
-
Tips For Introducing A Pacifier:
1️⃣ Offer when baby is calm, not hungry or tired, and swaddled.
2️⃣ Apply pressure in the middle of baby’s tongue and move the pacifier in circles around his mouth.
3️⃣ If baby becomes frustrated, stop🛑 and try again later.
4️⃣ Do not offer in lieu of a feeding...if your little one is hungry, a pacifier won’t satisfy.
5️⃣ Try different shapes and brands until you find one she likes.
6️⃣ Keep trying a few times each day for a week...if baby won’t take it, that’s FINE! It’s okay to move on.
-
‼️ Although pacifiers are a helpful tool, they are NOT a requirement for any of my classes. ‼️
You can have a great little sleeper and a happy baby with, or without, a pacifier. 😊
-
Does your baby take a pacifier? Did it come easily or did you have to work for it? What shape/brand works best for your baby?
-
The pacifiers shown here are by @ryanandrose. (Not an ad. Not a partnership. Just a great company.)

node.text:
That’s right! If you’ve got a new little “sitter,” it’s time to drop the mattress. ⁣
⁣
Let’s unpack this! ⁣
⁣
An infant’s head is much heavier in proportion to their body. This means your sweet little bobble-head truly is “top heavy.” ⁣
⁣
So, please remember this…⁣
⁣
⭐️𝘐𝘧 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘰𝘱 𝘤𝘳𝘪𝘣 𝘳𝘢𝘪𝘭 𝘪𝘴 𝘭𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘯 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘣𝘢𝘣𝘺’𝘴 𝘤𝘩𝘦𝘴𝘵, 𝘪𝘵 𝘮𝘢𝘬𝘦𝘴 𝘧𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘢 𝘩𝘶𝘨𝘦 𝘳𝘪𝘴𝘬.⁣⭐️⁣
⁣
To prevent falls, aim for the top rail to hit mid-chest when the baby is in a standing position, even if your little one can't stand yet!⁣
⁣
Please tag a parent...or lots of them! Let’s prevent crib accidents. Start watching your Instagram feed, how many babies do you see standing in cribs with the mattress not quite low enough? You’ll be amazed!😱 (Be sure to see stories for more common questions about this!⁣)⁣
⁣
What age was your baby when you knew it was time? Did it catch you off guard? Anyone start from the beginning with it in the lower position? (That’s okay too, btw!)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TAKING CARA BABIES "How can I prioritize sleep when my baby is sick?" Swipe for some practicaltips!'.

node.text:
Sleep IS good medicine, but sickness often causes disrupted sleep! ⁣
⁣
For more details, be sure to check out my blog post "Sleep and Sick Season: What’s a Parent to Do?" (Link in bio/stories!)⁣
⁣
Any "sick tips" you would add? How have you dealt with baby sickness in your house? How long did it take to get your good little sleeper back?⁣

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TAKING CARA BABIES "How can I prioritize sleep when my baby is sick?" Swipe for some practicaltips!'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '# Maintain a consistent nap nap-time and bedtime routine These familiar series of events cue your baby's brain that sleep is coming even when your little one isn't feeling well. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#2 Allow more daytime sleep While sick it's okay to let naps extend a bit longer than normal. Check on your little one frequently. Consider waking your little one after 2.5-3 hours for any given nap for feedings to maintain hydration. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#3 Camp out in baby's room Ifyou're wanting to be closer to your baby while she's sick, consider putting a mattress in her room for you to sleep on, rather than bringing her into your room. Babies sleep better in their normal sleep environment, just like you do! taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '#4 It's okay to give extra help Your great little sleeper may need more support than usual when falling asleep and back to sleep in the night. If you need to rock or snuggle your little one to get him sleeping while sick, go for it! taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#5 Offer night feedings when needed (even if previously weaned of all feedings) If baby hasn't eaten well during the day or is struggling with vomiting or diarrhea, she may need these extra feedings. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Mostimportantty. Give lots of snuggles and patience! Sick babies need a lot of extra love! taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"What about when baby is feeling better?" Jump right back to your normal healthy sleep habits! My online class "The ABC' of Sleep" is a plan that can be used anytime sleep is derailed and once your baby is back to 100% health, you can have your great little sleeper back in just a few days. taking cara babies'.

node.text:
Sleep sacks are one of my favorite tools to have in your sleep toolbox. 🛠💤⁣
⁣
Here are a few reasons why I LOVE sleep sacks:⁣
⁣
✅They cue the brain that it’s time for sleep.⁣
✅Unlike loose blankets, sleep sacks are safe, wearable, and actually stay on baby when rolling around the crib.⁣
✅They promote sleep by making crawling, walking, and climbing a bit more difficult. ⁣
✅They’re available in various weights and fabrics (perfect for every season!)⁣
⁣
See today’s stories for more details and a peek at some of my favorite sleep sacks!👀⁣
⁣
Does your baby use a sleep sack? Which brand is your favorite? ⁣

node.text:
Look at all of those sweet babies falling asleep independently!😍⁣
⁣
✨Baby Sleep Tip:✨ Mastering this skill plays a HUGE part in achieving consolidated night sleep!⁣
⁣
But, here's the catch...⁣ No one actually "sleeps through the night!" We ALL wake up multiple times as we transition through sleep cycles! 😧⁣
⁣
𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲'𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻𝘀:⁣
1️⃣You wake at the end of each sleep cycle.⁣
2️⃣You briefly check your surroundings to make sure nothing has changed.⁣
3️⃣If everything looks good, you fall right back to sleep, often without even knowing you were awake.⁣
⁣
𝗕𝗨𝗧, 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻 𝗶𝗳...⁣
1️⃣You fell asleep in YOUR bed.⁣
2️⃣Two hours later, you wake up in your NEIGHBOR’S bed!!!😳 ⁣
3️⃣Would you just roll over and go back to sleep?⁣ No way! You would be so confused!😱⁣
⁣
Your baby has this SAME reaction when he wakes in a different environment than where he fell asleep. He will look for the same environment with the same interventions to fall BACK to sleep.⁣
⁣
Here's a better example... (Because "your neighbor's bed" isn't very realistic! 😂)⁣
✳If your little one is rocked/fed to sleep at bedtime, he will most likely need rocking/feeding throughout the night as he transitions between some sleep cycles. This is why falling asleep independently is VITAL!⁣
⁣
With that said, feel free to snuggle your baby and rock to sleep when desired, but falling asleep independently at bedtime will truly make your nights SO MUCH easier!💕⁣
⁣
💫Fun Fact: A small percentage of babies can be rocked/fed to sleep and sleep through the night. Remember, if it’s working for you, there’s no reason to change it!💫 ⁣
⁣
➡But…If you're struggling with this, my classes can help! Just click the link in my bio and select your baby's age to get started.⁣
➡If your little one 𝘤𝘢𝘯 fall asleep independently at bedtime, but still struggles through the night, you simply need a consistent approach to handle night wakings. My classes can help with this too!⁣
⁣
Be sure to tag me in your stories if you catch your little one falling asleep independently! I'd love to share some today!⁣
⁣
Anyone willing to share the craziest place they've ever fallen asleep?😱😴

node.text:
Parents, I have a very heavy, but important message to share.⁣
⁣
I never want to educate in a way that induces fear. But, with many of you traveling/having fun around water this summer, I need to talk to you about drowning, because it never feels like it could happen to you...until it does.⁣
⁣
⚠𝘗𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘴𝘦 𝘵𝘢𝘨 𝘢 𝘱𝘢𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘵/𝘤𝘢𝘳𝘦𝘨𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘳/𝘧𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘥 𝘣𝘦𝘭𝘰𝘸. 𝘛𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘪𝘯𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘮𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘚𝘈𝘝𝘌𝘚 𝘓𝘐𝘝𝘌𝘚!⚠⁣
⁣
Here are some important ways to prevent drowning and keep your little one safe:⁣
⁣
𝗔𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗲:⁣
➡ Install locks on toilets: littles are top-heavy and it only takes a bit of water.⁣
➡ Never leave a baby alone in the tub...not even for a second: It’s better to carry a dripping wet baby through the house than leaving him alone.⁣
➡ Empty ALL containers (buckets, kiddie pools, bathtubs, etc.) immediately after use and turn them upside down to prevent unintentional water collection.⁣
⁣
𝗔𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗼𝗼𝗹:⁣
➡ Never leave pool toys or floats in or around the pool: children can be tempted to reach into the pool to grab a toy.⁣
➡ Install a pool fence: baby proof your pool with a fence that is at least 4ft high, non-climbable, and has a self-latching/self-closing gate.⁣
➡ Add alarms to doors leading to the patio.⁣
➡ Can’t find your child? Always check the pool FIRST. It only takes seconds for a child to drown, which means every single second matters.⁣
⁣
𝗪𝗵𝗶𝗹𝗲 𝗮𝘁 𝗚𝗮𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀:⁣
➡ Have a designated “water watcher.”⁣
➡ Alternate “water watchers” every 15 minutes: This ensures everyone gets socialization, but kids are being actively monitored too.⁣
⁣
✳And please, look into survival swim classes for your children and CPR training for you and all caregivers. If all other preventative measures fail, this type of training may be the very thing that saves your child’s life.⁣
⁣
Please tag ALL of the parents you know! Share this post! ❤️ By sharing this post with others, you can prevent a tragedy! You can save lives!⁣
⁣

node.text:
This topic can be a cause of concern for many, so I want to address it in hopes of calming your heart.⁣
⁣
Here's what we know: Restorative sleep is VITAL for proper development. But so is a secure parent/child attachment!⁣
⁣
⭐Here's the great news: Research shows that sleep training is not only effective, but it also decreases infant stress, decreases maternal stress, and parent-child attachment remains unchanged.⭐️ (See stories for research)⁣
⁣
Formal sleep training at Taking Cara Babies (which only begins at 5+ months) uses a hands-on approach that gives you an active role in helping your baby become a great little sleeper, all while protecting that special bond you've created.🙌 You’ll have a step-by-step plan to teach you how to help your baby sleep 10+ hours each night while remaining emotionally connected. ⁣
⁣
➡️Sleep training does NOT mean you have to give up the activities you love doing, like rocking, cuddling, and singing to them.⁣
⁣
➡️Sleep training does NOT mean you have to drop night feedings cold turkey. I’ll help you gradually wean night feedings or maintain one if that’s needed too!⁣
⁣
➡️Sleep training does NOT mean you have to give up snuggle naps if you enjoy them! You can do nights & naps separately if it works best for YOUR family.⁣
⁣
➕Babies who sleep well tend to have an easier temperament, are more adaptable, and less fussy. Consolidated sleep boosts babies’ cognition, immunity, and emotional regulation too. ⁣
➕The benefits don’t stop with babies! Research shows that moms who are well-rested have less incidence of depression and anxiety. It’s not about being selfish- when moms are rested, they are emotionally available for their babies.⁣
⁣
I need you to hear this: If sleep training isn't for you, that's okay! If what you are doing is working, there’s no reason to change it! In fact, many families who lay a healthy sleep foundation with my newborn class or First Five Months Bundle may never need to sleep train at all. ⁣
⁣
Was sleep training the right answer for your family? Did you feel your bond with baby strengthen as a result of restful nights like I did? How did you know it was the right choice for YOUR family?

node.text:
This week was all about showing you that travel can be fun and a time to make great memories… even with little ones! 💕⁣
⁣
Sure, naps will be off, night sleep may be a bit wonky, and you’ll do things a bit differently than at home.⁣
⁣
𝘛𝘩𝘢𝘵’𝘴 𝘰𝘬𝘢𝘺! ⁣
⁣
What’s the trick to getting baby back on track AFTER you get home?!⁣
⁣
𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗶𝘁 𝗶𝘀: ⁣
⁣
⭐️Night One, you go right back to your consistent habits and behaviors. ⭐️⁣
⁣
No matter what nights and naps looked like while traveling, NIGHT ONE is the time to go RIGHT BACK to your NORMAL approach! ⁣
⁣
Again: ⁣
What happens on vacation stays on vacation. We don’t bring those habits home with us! ⁣
⁣
❌Late bedtimes- no more!⁣
❌Newly added night feedings-goodbye!⁣
❌Coming to sleep with Mama-done with that!⁣
❌Up before dawn- nope! ⁣
❌Only napping in the stroller- hello crib! ⁣
⁣
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗻𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝗱𝗮𝘆:⁣
➕Wake your baby by 7-7:30am to start back on a normal routine.⁣
➕Give ample time for active floor play (rolling, crawling, scooting, walking, etc).⁣
➕Get outside if possible because daylight helps reset that internal clock and promotes good night sleep.⁣
➕Be uber consistent with naps and wake windows.⁣
⁣
Truly, 1-3 consistent days and nights and your great little sleeper will re-emerge!⁣
(If you’ve taken “The ABC’s of Sleep,” implement your plan- you’ll see that great little sleeper once again in no time at all.)⁣
⁣
🧳 I want vacation to be something you truly relish and enjoy! My hope is that no matter what happens on vacation, you never need to stress because you KNOW all it takes is 1-3 nights back home and that great sleeper is back. ⁣
⁣
⭐️ Now, if baby sleep is always tough and you haven’t found an approach that works, know that I have classes to help! “The ABC’s of Sleep” is for 5-24 month olds. It’s a 14 night plan to 10-12 hour nights in the crib.⁣
⁣
Have you traveled with your baby? How was sleep after you got home? Any additional tips for getting baby back on track?⁣

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 08, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'NE EXPERT! GET What are your best tips for traveling with baby? taking cara babies'.

node.text:
It’s your turn! Experience is often the best teacher! ⁣
All week I’ve been sharing my best tips for traveling with little ones, but now I want to hear from YOU! 😊⁣
⁣
Tell us:⁣
❓What kind of trips have you taken with babies? Have you tried camping, amusement parks, the beach?⁣
❓Any special tips for handling naps and night sleep while traveling?⁣
❓What helped most on those long road trips?⁣
❓Any advice for handling extended family and little ones?⁣
❓What are your “go-to” supplies that make traveling with kiddos a bit easier? ⁣
⁣
If you have travel photos or videos, I’d love to see those too!! ⁣
💕 Share them in your stories and be sure to tag @takingcarababies. ⁣
And… can I get a 🙋🏼‍♂️🙋🏼‍♀️🙋🏽 for all those who have turned a hotel bathroom into a temporary nursery!

node.text:
Soft sand, crashing waves, and endless sunshine are the perfect setting for making memories (and sandcastles!), but being out in the heat all day can feel a little tricky with a baby.🏖️👶⁣
⁣
Here are a few more tips to help make your beach day a breeze:⁣
☀️Pack a portable fan + beach umbrella. Keeping baby cool and out of the sun is essential. (AAP says shade instead of sunscreen for babies younger than 6 months.)⁣
☀️For older babies: pack lots of sunscreen and reapply often. A makeup brush/sponge can make sunscreen application so easy!⁣
☀️Pack a portable sound machine. White noise + the soothing sound of the waves should help you set up a calm sleep environment for baby.⁣
☀️Aim for a "normal" bedtime range. Try to head back in time for your bedtime routine and put baby down at a decent time. Your baby will be ready for bed after a long day at the beach!⁣
☀️Be flexible! Focus on having a great time and know that your schedule might look a little different while at the beach.⁣
⁣
What's your favorite tip for beach days with a baby? Anyone have any "beach hacks" to share?

node.text:
Anyone recently travel to a different time zone? How'd it go? What tips do you have to help make that adjustment easier? ⁣
⁣
❤️My best memories with my kiddos on vacations occurred when I let go of unrealistic expectations! Here are some things I’ve learned along the way: ⁣
➡️Expect the first few nights to be a little rocky. This is normal.⁣
➡ Middle of the night waking on vacation doesn’t mean you’ve lost your good sleeper. Don’t stress about that! ⁣
➡️Watch your child more than the clock!⁣
➡ Let go of perfection, make those memories, and have lots of fun!⁣
➡ When you get home, jump right back to your normal routine on your first day home. Your baby might be “off” for 3-4 days/nights. It’s okay: you probably will be too.⁣
⁣
If you get home and sleep is extra tough, I’m here for you! My classes will help you have a great little sleeper and will give you the tools to travel with confidence + conquer any sleep setbacks that may arise! 🙌💕⁣
⁣
Anyone heading to some place fun? ✈ If so, we all want the deets! What exciting places are you visiting?!😍

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#2 If your trip is longer than 3 days, try to adjust to local time. Start by capping baby's naps at 2 hours max. Longer naps only prolong the adjustment. Be sure to cap the last nap of the day to promote a full wake window before a 7-8pm bedtime in the new time zone. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#3 Wake baby at 7am local time. This helps set that internal clock and starts baby's day in the new time zone. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#4 Aim for full wake windows throughout the day and watch for sleepy cues. An undertired/overtired baby can result in fussiness and disrupted sleep taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#5 Don't forget floor play and physical activity. While traveling, babies are often moved from strollers to car seats to carriers. Don't forget, littles need to be physica and move those bodies in order to sleep well. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#6 Naps on-the-go are to be expected, but aim for at least one nap a day in the crib or pack oack-n-play for a more restorative nap. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#7 Maintain a consistent bedtime routine. Keep the room dark and be sure to avoid screen time before bedtime. taking cara babies'.

Photo by Taking Cara Babies: Baby Sleep on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#8 If your little one is awake during the night or early morning hours keep lights dimmed, electronics off, and activity minimal. taking cara babies'.

node.text:
Traveling with your baby can seem daunting - it requires a lot of extra work! But, the memories you'll make on your trip will be worth it all.💕⁣
⁣
Before we dive deeper into those travel tips, let me remind you: the day of travel WILL be “off”. Trying to maintain a “perfect schedule” will only set you up for failure and frustration. Do your best to really focus on living in the moment and remember your goal: arriving at your destination. Plan that naps, wake windows, feedings, and attitudes will be a bit “off” on this day! ⁣
⁣
Now, for those tips: ⁣
⁣
If you're flying...✈️⁣
✅Leave a little early for the airport. Traveling with a baby takes a bit more time than traveling solo.⁣
✅Babywear so that you're hands-free while at the airport. ⁣
✅Change baby's diaper before boarding: those airplane bathrooms are so small! Consider nighttime diapers for extra absorbency. ⁣
✅Offer pacifier or feed during takeoff/landing to help with the "ear-popping" sensation.⁣
✅Bring a new toy. This is so helpful if your baby starts to get fussy mid-flight!⁣
⁣
⁣
If you're driving...🚗⁣
✅Decide between night driving/day driving ahead of time. Both have their pros and cons. As always, find what's best for your baby and your family.⁣
✅Be flexible and prepare for frequent stops. Stop every 2 hours for a quick bathroom break (or more often if needed) and get baby out of the car seat to get those wiggles out.⁣
✅Pack plenty of snacks for older babies/toddlers and extra formula for infants.⁣
✅Window clings helps keep the environment cool and dark.⁣
⁣
If you're currently pumping: don't forget your pumping supplies and a cooler for milk storage (Tip: a manual pump or pump with a car adapter can be perfect for long road trips!)⁣
✅Feed and change your baby right before leaving to buy some time before you have to make your first stop.⁣
✅Bring a portable sound machine to help block out sound when baby falls asleep.⁣
⁣
Have you had a successful flight/road trip with your baby? What tips would you add to my list? Any advice or words of encouragement for parents with an upcoming trip?
